sourceResource.title: "Lord Here I Am", Kenneth Glover, [s.d]
sourceResource.description: LP of "'Lord Here I Am', Kenneth Glover". [Cover page]: Photograph of Kenneth Glover sitting outside on a garden bed. [Back cover page]: "'Lord Here I Am', Kenneth Glover". A brief biography about Kenneth Glover. Four photographs of Kenneth Glover outside with garden in background. Side one: 1. 'Just Tell Jesus'; 2. 'His Eye Is On The Sparrow; 3. 'Christ Is All'; 4. 'Close To Thee'; 5. 'Lose Your Pride'; 6. 'He's Everything'. Side two: 1. 'Lord Here I Am'; 2. 'The Lord Will Make A Way Somehow'; 3. 'When I've Done The Best I Can'; 4. Rock Of Ages; 5. Why Shouldn't I Serve The Lord; 6. 'Do You Know Him'". Other Kenneth Glover albums listed.; Side 1 of disc: "'Lord Here I am', Kenneth Glover. Side 1. B/K Productions. Los Angeles, California. Stereo. 1005. 33 1/3 RPM. 1. 'Just Tell Jesus'; 2. 'His Eye Is On The Sparrow; 3. 'Christ Is All'; 4. 'Close To Thee'; 5. 'Lose Your Pride'; 6. 'He's Everything'".; Side 2 of disc: "'Lord Here I am', Kenneth Glover. Side 2. B/K Productions. Los Angeles, California. Stereo. 1005. 33 1/3 RPM. 1. 'Lord Here I Am'; 2. 'The Lord Will Make A Way Somehow'; 3. 'When I've Done The Best I Can'; 4. Rock Of Ages; 5. Why Shouldn't I Serve The Lord; 6. 'Do You Know Him'".

sourceResource.title: Spirituals in rhythm, Sister Rosetta Tharpe [s.d]
Spirituals in rhythm, Sister Rosetta Tharpe [s.d]
sourceResource.description: LP of "Sister Rosetta Tharpe, Spirituals in Rhythm". [Cover page]: Photograph of Rosetta Tharpe's face, and repeated pairs of clapping hands on cover. [Back cover page (2)]: "Sister Rosetta Tharpe" and short biography written on back cover. "Side A: Nothing between; He's the lily of the valley; Seeking for me; Shine for Jesus; Never Alone; I do, don't you. Side B: God leads us along; The family prayer; What are they doin' in heaven; I saw the light; Blow ye the trumpet in Zion; Oh, the joy that came to me. Diplomat Records; This is a Diplomat Long Playing 33 1/2 RPM Record, unbreakable under normal use. For greater enjoyment it should alwasy be kept away from head and stored in this sleeve. Dust and dirt should be removed from this record with lint free cloth. Mfg. by Synthetic Plastics Co., Newark, N. J.".; "Sister Rosetta Tharpe. 2234-A; Side 1" and song list on side 1 of record. "Sister Rosetta Tharpe. 2234-B; Side 2" and song list on side 2 of record. For complete song lists see description of back cover, above.

The core of the group was usually lead Jethro Bledsoe, tenor Robert Reed, and bass singer Earl Malone, all of whom joined in the 1930s. [http://www.allmusic.com]

sourceResource.title: Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 4:
Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 4:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:10 : Mary Yoon marries Charles Yoon, counter to same-surname marriage.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:35 : Col. Kim remains close to Charles Yoon because Nora and Mary were close.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:01 : Pre-World War II Korean community in Los Angeles was small.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 01:18 : Asian community divided at that time; interactions among second generation, in school.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 02:01 : Community disapproval of marrying outside of the community.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 02:12 : Attends Central Junior High; Chinatown located at present-day Union Station.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 03:40 : Present-day Chinatown was Little Italy at that time.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 04:19 : Real estate against Asians in this period; Italians controlled landholdings in Chinatown.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 04:23 : Former name of Hill Street (unclear).; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 05:37 : Other large ethnic groups at school: Mexicans, then Caucasians.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 06:35 : First two schools in Los Angeles--California Street School and Central Junior High (became Los Angeles High); Jews in Brooklyn Heights.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 08:31 : After World War II, Jews moved to Fairfax area.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 08:55 : Ethnic groups in school--Mexicans, Italians, Chinese, Japanese, Caucasians, a few Blacks and Koreans.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 09:24 : Ostracized by non-Korean parents of other children.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 09:55 : 90% of Japanese, Chinese, Korean children attended language school.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 10;19 : Describes childhood Caucasian friend.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 10:58 : Learns to be comfortable with other races early in life.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 11:35 : Third wife a much younger Vietnamese woman (34 years old).; Unit_ID: detail019.--Title: 12:38 : Meets third wife by chance.; Unit_ID: detail020.--Title: 12:52 : Admits to major marital problems due to generational differences.; Unit_ID: detail021.--Title: 14:13 : Col. Kim has no children; first two wives had hysterectomies.; Unit_ID: detail022.--Title: 15:57 : Loves children and dogs.

sourceResource.title: Rev. Kyong-t'ae Kang: Segment 2:
description: Interview abstract: Topics covered include Minister Kang's childhood and education under Japanese rule, escape from North Korea in 1949, the Korean War and postwar South Korea, his emigration to the USA in 1973, and Korean entrepreneurship in America.

Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:12 : Uncle has enough food to feed Minister Kang.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:57 : Father urges him to go to South Korea.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:05 : Description of where siblings lived.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 01:58 : Does not recall when or how parents became Christians.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 02:12 : Born into a Christian family.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 02:26 : Church located six miles from his village, near the school.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 02:48 : 150 church members.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 03:35 : Church run by Koreans.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 03:42 : American missionaries visit the church once a year.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 03:51 : Church is Presbyterian.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 04:02 : Japanese send police to monitor the Church.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 04:45 : Father arrested for refusing to bow to Shinto shrine; imprisoned for a year.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 05:02 : Father beaten by Japanese police.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 05:10 : Father imprisoned 1939-1940; family suffers, Rev Kang is 5 years old.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 06:15 : Japanese confiscate village crops; widespread hunger.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 07:15 : Older brother conscripted, taken to Kobu, Japan as factory worker.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 07:51 : Brother returns after World War II.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 08:17 : Recalls first time he saw his father cry, when he received a letter from his brother.; Unit_ID: detail019.--Title: 09:01 : Escapes from North Korea with sister in May 1949.; Unit_ID: detail020.--Title: 09:27 : Family holds farewell dinner before his departure.; Unit_ID: detail021.--Title: 10:00 : Fear of neighbor turning them in.; Unit_ID: detail022.--Title: 10:17 : Father hoped Rev Kang could return for 60th birthday; was 58 at the time--this was last time they met.; Unit_ID: detail023.--Title: 10:50 : At time of interview, Rev Kang is 60 years old.; Unit_ID: detail024.--Title: 11:02 : He and sister walk all night; board train at Hwang-ju to the 38th parallel.; Unit_ID: detail025.--Title: 12:57 : Gather with ten other people before crossing the border.; Unit_ID: detail026.--Title: 13:18 : Guide is an old Korean lady.; Unit_ID: detail027.--Title: 13:54 : Spends four days in Hae-ju.; Unit_ID: detail028.--Title: 14:09 : Crosses into South Korea at Kae-Sung (in the South prior to 1950).; Unit_ID: detail029.--Title: 14:32 : Kae-Sung becomes part of North after the Korean War.; Unit_ID: detail030.--Title: 14:52 : Danger of crossing the border.

subject.name: Charismatic Christians and military service in the USSR, 1950
KGB: psychological pressure on him and his family

rights: Ukrainian Evangelical Theological Seminary. Library of UETS
Contact: Oleg Bornovolokov, oleguets@ukr.net
Ukrainian Evangelical Theological Seminary
Library, Ukrainian Evangelical Theological Seminary, UETS, 57 Gamarnika St. Kiev-04075, Ukraine

relation: Ukrainian Evangelical Theological Seminary, Kyiv, Ukraine
creator: Muravlev, speaker
Муравлев, speaker
title: Testimony of Muravlev, [s.d.]
Свидетельство Муравлев
sourceResource.description: Mr. Muravlev talks about some tensions between him and his Commanding Officers while in the Soviet military (early 1950s) caused by the fact that he was a Pentecostal Christian. He briefly mentions a “six-day trial” in Saratov, USSR. He also talks about his arrest in April of 1961, a pressure applied by the KGB on him and his family as well as conditions in general under the Soviet regime.

sourceResource.title: Rev. Kyong-t'ae Kang: Segment 4:
description: Interview abstract: Topics covered include Minister Kang's childhood and education under Japanese rule, escape from North Korea in 1949, the Korean War and postwar South Korea, his emigration to the USA in 1973, and Korean entrepreneurship in America.

Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:11 : Arrives in Taegu, searches for church.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:38 : Young-nak Church in Seoul, meeting place for North Koreans.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:05 : Young-nak located in Chung-ku district in Seoul.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 02:00 : Arrives in Taegu in January 1951.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 02:08 : Stays in Taegu for three years.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 02:20 : Cannot afford to attend school, works a series of jobs, including railroad porter.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 03:38 : Nephews attend primary school.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 04:08 : During war, Taegu was fifteen miles from the fighting front.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 04:27 : Able to hear artillery fire.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 04:36 : Seoul teeming with refugees and soldiers.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 05:02 : Lives with sister and her family on edge of Taegu.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 05:29 : Rents single room from a farmer.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 05:57 : Resumes secondary education in 1954 at Christian school near Pusan.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 06:09 : Brother-in-law is vice principal of the school.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 06:51 : Lives with sister and brother-in-law while attending high school.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 06:59 : One sister remains in Taegu.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 07:13 : High school located in small town called Jin-young.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 08:10 : Another sister also stays in same house.; Unit_ID: detail019.--Title: 08:28 : Finishes high school and starts college in Seoul.; Unit_ID: detail020.--Title: 08:41 : Moves to Seoul to finish high school; lives with best friend's family.; Unit_ID: detail021.--Title: 09:40 : Finishes high school in Seoul.; Unit_ID: detail022.--Title: 09:52 : Studies Korean literature and journalism in college.; Unit_ID: detail023.--Title: 10:06 : Studies literature at Joong-ang University and journalism at Hong-Un University.; Unit_ID: detail024.--Title: 11:32 : After Korean War, age of students is older due to War's disruption.; Unit_ID: detail025.--Title: 12:05 : Graduates from high school at age 21.; Unit_ID: detail026.--Title: 12:23 : South Korea almost completely destroyed.; Unit_ID: detail027.--Title: 12:51 : Rebuilding of Seoul.; Unit_ID: detail028.--Title: 13:25 : In college, works part time; rents room and lives on his own.; Unit_ID: detail029.--Title: 13:54 : After college serves in the military.; Unit_ID: detail030.--Title: 14:21 : Graduates from college at age 26.; Unit_ID: detail031.--Title: 14:36 : Mandatory military service.

sourceResource.title: Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 1:
Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 1:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:26 : Father emigrates.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:33 : Father's name Shoon Kwon Kim.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 00:56 : Father emigrates with a male cousin.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 01:19 : Eva Kim is the daughter of father's cousin.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 01:38 : Unclear about father's history; learns it from his father's cousin; father works at a fruitstand.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 02:30 : Father emigrates because of Japanese occupation.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 03:09 : Father wants to emigrate to the continental US rather than Hawaii.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 03:34 : Paternal grandmother dies in childbirth.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 03:45 : Paternal grandfather does not remarry immediately.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 04:00 : Father also emigrates because of his father's remarriage to a young woman.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 04:18 : Learns father's history from mother and father's cousin.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 04:23 : Learns very little from father.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 04:29 : Father from middle class family that owned land along Inchon coast.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 05:13 : Family business--converting saltwater to salt.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 06:15 : Family leases landholdings to tenant farmers.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 06:34 : Considers father "spoiled rotten".; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 07:01 : Main reason for emigrating is Japanese occupation.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 07:15 : Father travels first from Inchon to Pusan.; Unit_ID: detail019.--Title: 07:26 : Father caught as a stowaway twice and sent back to Inchon; get to USA on third attempt.; Unit_ID: detail020.--Title: 07:49 : Father enters in either Hawaii or Seattle.; Unit_ID: detail021.--Title: 08:08 : Seattle a major entrypoint for Koreans.; Unit_ID: detail022.--Title: 08:29 : Father works as migrant farmer; comes to Southern California.; Unit_ID: detail023.--Title: 08:35 : Father's cousin settles in Reedley, California.; Unit_ID: detail024.--Title: 08:45 : Father continues to Los Angeles.; Unit_ID: detail025.--Title: 09:10 : Father works a range of jobs in Los Angeles.; Unit_ID: detail026.--Title: 10:33 : Father attends night school to learn English.; Unit_ID: detail027.--Title: 10:58 : Father reads American newspapers; follows American politics.; Unit_ID: detail028.--Title: 11:11 : Father participates in American politics.; Unit_ID: detail029.--Title: 12:00 : Father mainly involved in Korean nationalist politics.; Unit_ID: detail030.--Title: 12:23 : Father a leader in Syngman Rhee's faction.; Unit_ID: detail031.--Title: 12:34 : Father a leader of Tongjihoe.; Unit_ID: detail032.--Title: 12:58 : Col. Kim meets Syngman Rhee during Korean War.

sourceResource.title: Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 6:
Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 6:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:21 : Walter McMath Jr.'s nickname was "Speedy".; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:51 : Kristen McMath's son 27-28 years old.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:08 : Walter McMath Jr. in his 40s.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 01:23 : Brother, Jack Kim, widowed, was married to a Mexican American woman named Angelina; three children.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 03:52 : Brother, Philip Kim, married to a Caucasian woman named Wanda (from Oklahoma).; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 04:18 : Philip and Wanda no biological children; adopted a girl who was retarded.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 05:38 : Brother, Henry Kim, married a woman named Francis; two children.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 07:00 : Philip and Henry both have poor health due to poor diet and smoking.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 08:09 : Henry and Francis' children in their 40s.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 12:19 : Walter McMath Jr. and Henry Kim Jr gun nuts.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 12:38 : Describes himself as a gun nut.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 13:00 : Describes himself as expert marksman, which advanced his military career.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 13:10 : Sister, Mary Kim, is a good shot.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 14:19 : Mother from a farming family from Suwon, 60 miles south of Seoul; Father's family from Inchon.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 15:25 : Speculates that parents were betrothed prior to their births.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 15:44 : Never met mother's extended family; brother Henry met mother's family in Suwon after World War II.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 16:16 : Col. Kim visited Inchon during the Korean War.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 16:36 : Describes devastation of southern part of Korea after the Korean War.

sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:01 Fremont Elementary School, Central Junior High School.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 02:47 Polytechnic High School not as enjoyable; lonesome.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 05:02 Church in a house on Bunker Hill; social activities.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 06:10 Graduated in 1928.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 06:21 High school in Riverside for a short time.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 08:00 Graduated from Polytechnic; briefly work at father's fruit stand.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 08:59 Family moves to 35th Street to the emergent Korean neighborhood.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 09:55 Harvey Ahn's employment agency directs her to a job at I. Magnin's; worked there 1928-1940.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 11:44 Asked to bring other girls to work at I, Magnin's ; big advance for Korean girls.

sourceResource.title: John Kyudong Han: Segment 3:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:00 : Korean National Association leadership after An Chang Ho's death.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 01:57 : American government's support of Syngman Rhee.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 02:38 : Working at Sinhan Minbo and as a printer.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 05:44 : Worked for the California Test Bureau, forerunner of the SAT.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 06:52 : Bought a Model A in high school.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 09:00 : World War II, left the print shop to work at North American Aviation as a technical illustrator.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 11:38 : Father had had a stroke at the time of the Pearl Harbor attack.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 12:51 : Tried interior decorating, failed, went to work at Hughes Aircraft.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 13:44 : Continued to work at Sinhan Minbo in the evenings.

originalRecord.label: John Kyudong Han: Segment 3:
originalRecord.title: John Kyudong Han: Segment 3:
originalRecord.description: Unit_ID: detail001. -- Title: 00:00 : Korean National Association leadership after An Chang Ho's death.; Unit_ID: detail002. -- Title: 01:57 : American government's support of Syngman Rhee.; Unit_ID: detail003. -- Title: 02:38 : Working at Sinhan Minbo and as a printer.; Unit_ID: detail004. -- Title: 05:44 : Worked for the California Test Bureau, forerunner of the SAT.; Unit_ID: detail005. -- Title: 06:52 : Bought a Model A in high school.; Unit_ID: detail006. -- Title: 09:00 : World War II, left the print shop to work at North American Aviation as a technical illustrator.; Unit_ID: detail007. -- Title: 11:38 : Father had had a stroke at the time of the Pearl Harbor attack.; Unit_ID: detail008. -- Title: 12:51 : Tried interior decorating, failed, went to work at Hughes Aircraft.; Unit_ID: detail009. -- Title: 13:44 : Continued to work at Sinhan Minbo in the evenings.

sourceResource.title: John Kyudong Han: Segment 1:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:47 : Father came ca 1908 as contract laborer on Maui; supporter of Kongminhoe.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 02:22 : Father had been rice merchant in Korea.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 04:09 : Mother was housewife; her father had been a physician to the Queen; came to Hawaii ca 1911-1913.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 05:27 : Father bribed plantation gatekeeper to escape to Honolulu.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 06:45 : Father was active in Kongminhoe.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 07:57 : Three strategies to achieve independence.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 08:33 : Pak Youngman and the pilot training school (in Willows).; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 09:09 : John was born in 1918 in Honolulu, but moved soon to San Francisco.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 10:38 : Father had a cigar stand in San Francisco; continued political activities.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 11:46 : John in school.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 14:11 : Korean Methodist church in Fillmore district.

sourceResource.title: Daniel Bhang / Audrey Bhang Lee: Segment 4:
Daniel Bhang / Audrey Bhang Lee: Segment 4:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:03 : Daniel could not relate to Korean culture.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:43 : Audrey developed tuberculosis in St. Joseph and went to a TB sanitarium for 39 months.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:58 : Audrey became a Christian at the sanitarium and this was also the beginning of her independence.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 04:03 : Daniel stayed in Indianapolis while the family moved to St. Louis.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 04:59 : Daniel ate in a Chinese-American restaurant belonging to John, a Korean student at Indiana University.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 06:03 : Audrey had date John a couple times, without Father's knowledge.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 10:49 : Ben Limb was another friend of the family.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 11:34 : Audrey went to Spring Harbor Junior College for 3 years and supported herself doing housework.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 13:17 : After Audrey graduated, she went to join the family in St Louis to help take care of new baby brother, David.

sourceResource.title: Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 5:
Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 5:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:09 : Describes himself as outspoken and honest.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:35 : Greatest failing--too honest, too blunt; has hurt his career.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:12 : Run-in with Harold K. Johnson, Chief of Staff during Vietnam War, over use of helicopters in Vietnam.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 04:01 : Loves children; brother-in-law, William ?, famous children's author.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 05:46 : Describes dogsitting.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 07:46 : Once owned a Maltese.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 09:24 : Love of children; involvement with Japanese American National Museum, making it child-friendly.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 11:11 : Japanese American National Museum has too many academic curators.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 11:34 : Differences between children and adults; adults too set in beliefs.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 13:00 : Sister, Mary, married to Walter McMath; has three children.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 13:39 : Diane 50 years old; Kristen deceased for 20 years.

Johnson, Chief of Staff during Vietnam War, over use of helicopters in Vietnam.; Unit_ID: detail004. -- Title: 04:01 : Loves children; brother-in-law, William ?, famous children's author.; Unit_ID: detail005. -- Title: 05:46 : Describes dogsitting.; Unit_ID: detail006. -- Title: 07:46 : Once owned a Maltese.; Unit_ID: detail007. -- Title: 09:24 : Love of children; involvement with Japanese American National Museum, making it child-friendly.; Unit_ID: detail008. -- Title: 11:11 : Japanese American National Museum has too many academic curators.; Unit_ID: detail009. -- Title: 11:34 : Differences between children and adults; adults too set in beliefs.; Unit_ID: detail010. -- Title: 13:00 : Sister, Mary, married to Walter McMath; has three children.; Unit_ID: detail011. -- Title: 13:39 : Diane 50 years old; Kristen deceased for 20 years.

sourceResource.title: Rev. Kyong-t'ae Kang: Segment 3:
description: Interview abstract: Topics covered include Minister Kang's childhood and education under Japanese rule, escape from North Korea in 1949, the Korean War and postwar South Korea, his emigration to the USA in 1973, and Korean entrepreneurship in America.

Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:01 : Crossing the border from North to South Korea.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:45 : Sneaking by armed guards.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:22 : Military skirmishes at the 38th parallel in 1949.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 02:00 : South Korea police monitor border for spies from North; Rev Kang is 14 years old at crossing.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 02:36 : Rev Kang is the youngest in his group crossing the border.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 03:02 : Stays at the border for five days.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 03:14 : Takes a train to Seoul.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 04:01 : Guided across border at night by an old South Korean lady.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 04:28 : Stays in Chungdan before crossing the border to Kaesung.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 05:30 : Sister is 17 years old at time of crossing.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 05:40 : Sister married at 16 years and now lives in South Korea.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 06:10 : Another sister crossed border with her family in 1946.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 06:29 : Brother-in-law was a Christian radio drama writer.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 07:17 : Brother-in-law spends a year in North Korean prison for Christian beliefs.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 09:11 : Korean orphanage (this section unclear).; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 10:12 : Border was relatively open until the late 1940s.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 11:06 : Studies English in Seoul.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 11:21 : Lives with older sister.; Unit_ID: detail019.--Title: 12:34 : Attends high school; arrives in South Korea on 6/1/1949 and war breaks out a year later.; Unit_ID: detail020.--Title: 13:06 : 6/28/1950, North Korean soldiers occupy older sister's house, searching for playwright husband.; Unit_ID: detail021.--Title: 13:32 : Brother-in-law had escaped further south.; Unit_ID: detail022.--Title: 14:18 : Stays in Seoul until December 1950.; Unit_ID: detail023.--Title: 15:35 : China enters war; Seoul invaded by "red people".; Unit_ID: detail024.--Title: 15:55 : Flees by train to Taegu.; Unit_ID: detail025.--Title: 17:05 : Escapes from Seoul with his sisters.

Richard Hahn / Julia Kim Hahn: Segment 4:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:01 : Korean spoken at home but Mother gradually picked up English.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 02:13 : Richard loved aviation but was not accepted into Army aviation because he was Korean.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 04:17 : Went to aviation training center in Bakersfield.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 05:10 : Enlists in Navy as aviation machinist mate; Navy tried to give him other assignments, but he insisted on his original orders.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 09:28 : Transferred off of the .; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 10:14 : Hears that the had been sunk in Philippines.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 12:14 : In the Navy, was "treated like any other Asiatic would be treated".; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 15:29 : Passed over for officer training school.

sourceResource.title: The best of Andraé Crouch
sourceResource.description: LP. "The best of Andraé Crouch". [Cover page]: "The best of Andraé. Andraé Crouch and the Disciples." Cover picture of Andraé singing at the keyboard with microphone. [Page 2]: List of song titles for sides one and two on first disc. Photographic images of Andraé, the disciples, and an audience. [Page 3]: Liner note explains significance of release date and compilation of songs on the record, signed, "Love, Andraé." List of song titles for sides three and four on second disc. Light Records, copyright "1975 Lexicon Music, Inc.". More photographs of Andraé Crouch and the Disciples.; [Back cover page]: Photograph of Andrae Crouch and the Disciples. Song list reads, "Take a little time; Everything changed; Tell them; I'm gonna keep on singin'; My tribute; Bless His holy name; I'm coming home; Just like He said He would; If heaven never was promised; Take me back; Jesus is the answer; Through it all; Satisfied; Jesus (every hour--power); I come that you might have life; I know know why; I didnt' think it could be; Oh I need Him; I've got confidence; It won't be long". Credits read, "Producers: Bill Cole, Andraé Crouch, Bill Maxwell. Music arrangers: Andraé Crouch, Jimmie Owens, Clark Gassman, Fletcher Wiley, Larry Muhoberac, Gene Page. Design: Paul Hanson. Cover photography: Paul Slaughter. Personal management: David Wayne Management; 8721 Sunset Blvd. Suite 211; Hollywood, Ca. 90069. Phone: 213/657-6440. We would like to thank the following people for many reasons: Ralph Carmichael and Light Records; Jimmie Owens; Audrey Mieir; Bill Murray and all the participating musicians".

sourceResource.title: Let us go into the house of the Lord, 1968
Let us go into the house of the Lord, 1968
sourceResource.description: LP Let us go into the house of the Lord. [Cover page]: "Northern California State Youth Choir; Director Edwin. R. Hawkins; Let us go into the house of the Lord; Church of God in Christ" written on cover page. The image is yellow-orange and red warping circles. [Back cover page (2)]: Photograph of the choir in black and white. Text explains biography of the group. "Church of God in Christ of Northern California; State Y.P.W.W. President, Elder L.B. Johnson; State Chairlady, Sister Vada Turner; State Mother, Mother E.M. Devers; State Bishop E.B. Stewart; The YAMAHA grand piano was loaned for the recording by Miller Mills Music, Berkeley, California.; Description continues: "Side 1: 1. Let us go into the house of the Lord. 2. Jesus, lover of my soul. 3. To my Father's house. Soloist--Elaine Kelly. 4. I'm going through. Soloist--Margarette Branch. Side 2: 1. Oh happy day. Soloist--Dorothy Morrison. 2. I heard the voice of Jesus. Trio--Trumaine Davis, Rueben Franklin, Donald Cashmere. 3. Early in the morning. Soloist--Betty Watson. 4. Joy, joy. Soloists--Trumaine Davis, Ruth Lyons." All songs arranged by Edwin R. Hawkins. "Other Additional Records; Album #31016; CCRS. LaMont Bench; 5816 Lawton Avenue; Oakland, California 94618".; "Side 1. Northern California State Youth choir Church of God in Christ; Director Edwin R. Hawkins. Century Records, stereo 31016. LaMont Bench; 5816 Lawton Avenue; Oakland, California", song list (for complete list see description above), and "33 1/2"--on side 1 of the disc.; "Side 2. Northern California State Youth choir Church of God in Christ; Director Edwin R. Hawkins. Century Records, stereo 31016. LaMont Bench; 5816 Lawton Avenue; Oakland, California", song list (for complete list see description above), and "33 1/2"--on side 2 of the disc.; The Edwin Hawkins Singers began as The Northern California State Youth Choir founded in 1967 by Hawkins and Betty Watson, its members aged 17–25. As was common in gospel circles they produced and distributed their own LP: Let Us Go Into The House Of The Lord, recorded live in church. "Oh Happy Day", featuring Dorothy Morrison as lead vocalist, was picked up by a local DJ and subsequently released commercially. A hymn had never “crossed over” before. "Oh Happy Day" soared into the US Top 5, winning a Grammy and massive sales worldwide. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oh_Happy_Day]

sourceResource.title: Surely God is able; I need thee every hour, [s.d]
Surely God is able; I need thee every hour, [s.d]
sourceResource.description: Phonograph record. "Savoy Records; Surely God is able; Ward Singers; 4017-A; (GW-1); Sav-o-flex; Unbreakable under normal use; Not licensed for radiobroadcast--for home use on phonographs"--on one side. "Savoy Records; I need thee every hour; Ward Singers; 4017-B; (GW-2); Sav-o-flex; Unbreakable under normal use; Not licensed for radiobroadcast--for home use on phonographs"--on the other side.; Clara Ward (April 21, 1924 - January 16, 1973) Leader of The Famous Ward Singers. She ranks among the greatest of gospel singers; only Mahalia Jackson is more exalted. Her beautiful alto continues to delight music lovers. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clara_Ward]

sourceResource.title: Little Richard, ca. 1969-1970
sourceResource.description: LP. Little Richard. [Cover page]: "Little Richard. Gospel". Colorful charicature of Little Richard on stage with screaming audience. [Back page (2)]: "Little Richard. Richard Penniman, a lean, good looking kid..." short biography and information about styles that Little Richard influenced. "Side 1: Joy, joy, joy; Do you care; The captain calls for you; Do Lord, remember me; Ride on King Jesus. Side 2: (There'll be) Peace in the valley (for me); He's not just a soldier; My desire; He's my star". Photograph of Little Richard on back.; "Little Richard; Gospel!! SPC-3258-A. Side 1; Stereo"--side 1. Song list for side 1 included, see back page description for complete list. "Little Richard; Gospel!! SPC-3258-B. Side 2; Stereo"--side 2. Song list for side 2 included, see back page description for complete list. "Pickwick/33. A product of Pickwick International, Inc."--stamped on both sides of the phonograph record.; Rev. Richard Wayne Penniman (born December 5, 1932), is a celebrated American singer, songwriter and pianist, who began performing in the 1940s and was a key figure in the transition from rhythm & blues to rock and roll in the 1950s.
sourceResource.creator: Little Richard, 1932-, singer

sourceResource.description: Single. Record [page 1] reads: Specialty. Publisher: Venice Musie, Inc. BMI - 2:23. When I reach my heavenly home on high (D. Love--E. Starks). sourceResource.title: Al Green, Precious Lord, 1982
sourceResource.description: LP of "Al Green, Precious Lord". [Cover page]: Photograph of Al Green in a suit and tie on cover [Back cover page]: "Whereas, I have considered all not knowing all, I have thought id at all possible to save my life. In so doing, turning from the way of destruction, I thought it all necessary to grapple with these necessary things to bring myself and others to a pleasant tide of life. Al Green. Full Gospel Tabernacle Ministries. P.O. Box 9485, Memphis, TN 38109. 1: 'Precious Lord', Thomas A. Dorsey; 'What a Friend We Have in Jesus', arr. Al Green; 'The Old Rugged Cross', George Bennard; 'Morningstar', Moses Dillard-Sharon Michalsky; 'How Great Thou Art', Stuart Hine. 2: 'Glory to His Name', arr. Al Green; 'Rock of Ages', arr. Al Green; 'In the Garden', C. Austin Miles; 'Hallelujah (I Just Want to Praise the Lord)', Al Green-Moses Dillard". List of musicians, background vocals, and special thanks.; Side 1 of disc: "Precious Lord, Al Green. Produced by Al Green for Hi Records. Associate Producers: Bill Cantrell 2. 'What A Friend We Have in Jesus (arr. Al Green), (Butter Music/Al Green Music, Inc.-BMI-4:10); 3. The Old Rugged Cross (George Bennard), (The Rodeheaver Company-ASCAP-3:23); 4. Morningstar (Sharon Michalsky-Moses Dillard), (A-Line Publishing-ASCAP/Thumb Pick Music-Butter Music/Al Green Music, Inc.-BMI-3:22); 5. How Great Thou Art (Stuart K. Hine), (Manna Music-ASCAP-3:29)".; Side 2 of disc: "Precious Lord, Al Green. Produced by Al Green for Hi Records. Associate Producers: Bill Cantrell 2. 'Rock of Ages' (arr. Al Green), (Butter Music/ Al Green Music, Inc.-BMI-2:30); 3. 'In The Garden' (C. Austin Miles), (The Rodeheaver Company-ASCAP-3:54); 4. Hallelujah (I Just Want to Praise the Lord) (Al Green-Moses Dillard), (Butter Music/Al Green Music, Inc./Thumb Pick Music Inc.-BMI-4:34)".

sourceResource.title: John Somerville oral history, 1968
sourceResource.description: Interview of Dr. John Alexander Somerville and his wife Vada Somerville, by Robert Knutson, 1968 June 7. John Somerville was the first black graduate from the University of Southern California (the Dental School) in 1907. His wife, Vada, graduated from the USC Dental School in 1918.

subject.name: Prayers for freedom in the USSR
Prophecy about mass healing by praying
Mass healing in the village of Mayaki, Odessa Oblast’
Religious services and prayers in Tallinn, Estonia
History of the Tallinn Movement and Pentecostal Church in Eastern Europe and the USSR
New religious movements in the post-Soviet Ukraine
Ukraine – the center of religious awakening
Charismatic churches and movement in modern Ukraine
Rapidly growing number of Charismatic churches in modern Ukraine
History of the Pentecostal movement in the USSR and the post-Soviet period: Finland – Tallinn – Tartu – Tartu Bible School – Ukraine (1978 – present)
Migration of the Pentecostal Christians from the USSR to the USA
Spontaneous growth of Charismatic churches in Ukraine in the 2000s

American and other foreign missionaries in the Ukraine. New Pentecostal churches in Ukraine: “Oasis”, “Na Kuryernoi”(Kiev), “Forest”(a church and a Bible school near Kiev), “Obukhov”, “Pobeda” and “Zhivoe Slovo”

title: Tallinskoye probuzhdeniye - MTSKHL = Tallinn awakening - ICCL, ca. 2005 [interview]
Таллинское пробуждение - МЦХЛ, 2005? [interview]
description: Interview regarding the "Tallinskoye probuzhdeniye - Mezhdunarodnyy Tsentr Khristianskogo Liderstva (MTSKHL)" [Tallinn awakening - International Council for Christian Leadership (ICCL)], in Estonia, c.2005. Three Pentecostal Christians (Bishop Anatolii Petrovich, Valentina Ivanovna, Yuria (Yuriy)) talk about the rebirth of the Charismatic Movement in the USSR in 1970s. Originally centered in Tallinn, Estonia, USSR it moved later to Ukraine where it attracted tens of thousands of followers. The interviewer asks questions in English which are then translated into Russian by a translator , for the interviewees to respond in Russian which, in turn, are translated into English for the interviewer.

Интервью по поводу "[Таллинне пробуждение - Международный центр христианского лидерства (МЦХЛ), в Эстонии, {date?}. Интервьюер ({name}) задает вопросы на английском языке, которые затем переведены на русский язык переводчиком ({name}), для собеседника ({name}) реагировать на русском которая, в свою очередь, переводится на английский язык для интервьюера.

sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:10 : An Ch'ang-ho dies; Syngman Rhee asks Kim's father to pass on his condolences.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:41 : Father emigrates ca. 1913.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:13 : Sister Willa Kim born in 1917.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 01:17 : Mother emigrates in 1916.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 01:49 : Why father left Korea.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 02:30 : Mother's age at emigration unclear.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 02:43 : Mother had attended Methodist missionary school for women in Seoul; taught there.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 03:06 : Learns mother's history from Charles Yoon's mother.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 03:20 : Col. Kim close to Yoon family.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 03:26 : Mother studied to be a nurse.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 04:04 : Mother and father married as children.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 04:26 : Mother emigrates in late 1915 to attend University of Chicago on Methodist scholarship.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 05:25 : Mother arrives in Seattle; missionaries inform her husband against her wishes.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 05:57 : Mother cannot go to university because is married.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 06:10 : Mother goes to Walnut Creek, California instead of university.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 06:26 : Sister Willa Kim named after a missionary.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 06:49 : Jason Hur related to Charles Yoon by marriage.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 07:08 : Mother, from Seattle to Los Angeles, spent week in San Francisco crying.; Unit_ID: detail019.--Title: 08:43 : Parents had six children: Willa, Young, Mary, Jack, Philip, Henry.; Unit_ID: detail020.--Title: 09:28 : Col Kim the only sibling with a Korean name.; Unit_ID: detail021.--Title: 10:29 : Bothered by having a Korean name, at times.

sourceResource.title: John Kyudong Han: Segment 2:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:01 : Family left Sacramento ca 1928/1929.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:40 : Arguments in Korean National Association mostly about personalities and taking credit.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:41 : Family moved to Sacramento for John's asthyma, for one year.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 04:02 : From Sacramento, family went to Los Angeles, to area around USC.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 06:34 : Made most of his friends at John Adams Junion High School.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 08:00 : Manual Arts High School had a good art department; worked after school.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 09:24 : Non-Korean friends in high school.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 10:47 : Father worked as a janitor and sold ginseng.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 12:28 : Father had no personal animosity towards Japanese Americans.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 13:43 : Arguments in Korean National Association towards the end of the War.

sourceResource.title: Daniel Bhang / Audrey Bhang Lee: Segment 3:
Daniel Bhang / Audrey Bhang Lee: Segment 3:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:03 : Taken out of school for harvest work.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:40 : Father's lumber wagon.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:46 : Why Father decided to leave California for the Midwest.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 02:04 : Other children made fun of them, as Asians, but eventually, they were well accepted.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 03:45 : From Dowagiac, moved to Benton Harbor, then to Coloma (1929-1931).; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 05:36 : Mother woked with Father in their small Chinese-American restaurant.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 06:46 : Audrey worked in the restaurant after school and at lunchtime.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 08:24 : To St. Joseph, Michigan, then to Indianapolis, where they had a successful Chinese-American restaurant.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 10:00 : Daniel had a happy childhood, but was confused about ethnicity.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 11:39 : Some names of Daniel's teachers.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 12:15 : When Daniel first realized he was Korean.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 13:49 : Why did Father move so much and stay in the Midwest?.

sourceResource.title: Daniel Bhang / Audrey Bhang Lee: Segment 1:
Daniel Bhang / Audrey Bhang Lee: Segment 1:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:43 : Mother (Salome Lee) came to San Francisco in 1916 as picture bride.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 01:23 : Audrey is eldest of ten; Daniel is the third.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:51 : Father (Samuel K. Bhang) came to Hawaii as a stowaway at 17; did various jobs.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 03:34 : Father in restaurant business most of his life.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 04:03 : To Washington state, where Audrey was born in 1916.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 04:15 : Mistaken for Japanese, they were driven out of Washington and back to California, to farm.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 07:28 : Remembers taking lunch out to father as he was doing irrigation work.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 08:12 : From California to Chicago to open a restaurant, in 1924/25.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 08:47 : Considers Chicago her "jailhouse" because she was not allowed to go to school, but had to babysit the other children instead.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 12:05 : Father's restaurant business.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 13:20 : Went on her own to a band concert down the block.

sourceResource.title: Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 7:
Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 7:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:12 : Father an only son, Col. Kim believes.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:23 : Mother never spoke of her family; once married, belonged to husband's family.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:06 : Parents both bright, but mother pragmatic and father creative.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 02:10 : Mother's pragmatism attributed to family's farming background.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 02:36 : Asian women (from Asia) value men over women.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 03:21 : Korean folk story about woman who showed more loyalty to her in-laws than to her own family.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 05:16 : Women never spoiled in the Far East; more pragmatic and realistic than Asian men.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 06:04 : Mother worked 18-20 hours a day in family grocery store.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 06:50 : Kim family acquired grocery store at corner of Temple and Beaudry, at bottom of Court Street funicular.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 08:35 : 1920s, wealthier patrons phoned in orders to grocery store, but owners could only speak Korean.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 09:00 : Grocery store owners offer to sell store to Kim's parents with no down payment.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 09:34 : Mother did all the work; father undependable.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 09:59 : Father's role in store mainly linked to ability to speak English.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 10:12 : Mother managed store and its finances.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 10:31 : Repeats that mother worked 18-20 hours a day with little help from father.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 10:56 : Family grocery store had help--errand boy and a butcher.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 12:00 : Father's role in grocery store was minimal.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 12:27 : Father was smart but a bad worker; devoted too much time and money to Syngman Rhee and Tongjihoe.; Unit_ID: detail019.--Title: 12:59 : 1920s, grocery store made good money.; Unit_ID: detail020.--Title: 13:11 : Grocery store made $100 a day, but father gambled much of it away.; Unit_ID: detail021.--Title: 13:33 : 1920s-1930s, never well off because of father.; Unit_ID: detail022.--Title: 14:10 : Korean community was small, with close ties; most Korean immigrants were Christian.; Unit_ID: detail023.--Title: 15:13 : Church as community center.; Unit_ID: detail024.--Title: 16:50 : Role of Christianity among early Korean immigrants related to Japanese colonial rule.; Unit_ID: detail025.--Title: 18:01 : Early Korean immigrants attended church based on political affiliation.; Unit_ID: detail026.--Title: 18:40 : Church represented the one social outlet in Korean community.; Unit_ID: detail027.--Title: 19:23 : An Chang-Ho affiliated with Methodist Church; Tongjihoe with First Christian Church; Communist-leaning Koreans with Presbyterian Church.; Unit_ID: detail028.--Title: 20:40 : All factions worked for liberation of Korea from Japanese colonial rule.; Unit_ID: detail029.--Title: 21:11 : Col. Kim's family belonged to the First Christian Church.

Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 9:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 01:29 : Discussion of Col. Kim's move at the time of the interview.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 02:08 : Plans to move to Las Vegas; sister lives there.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 02:50 : Col. Kim seldom gambles.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 03:30 : Gambling.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 04:41 : Definition of family; friends versus family.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 05:59 : Bonds formed by the horrors of war different from those in normal life.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 06:38 : Can grow apart from family, but not from combat buddies.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 07:56 : Describes relationship with family in context of combat buddies.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 08:24 : Black sheep in families.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 10:01 : Differences between family and combat buddy relationships; popular with his nephews and nieces.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 11:01 : Brothers and sisters had financial difficulties; Col. sourceResource.title: Helen Lee Hong: Segment 2:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:00 Life with parents.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 01:28 Move away from Riverside to a series of other towns.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 02:06 Father's occupations.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 03:17 Riverside navel orange industry.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 03:59 Mrs. Stewart's involvement with Koreans in Upland.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 04:53 Mrs. Stewart's complaints.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 05:53 Mr. Stewart left only part of his fortune to his wife, for fear she would have given it away too freely.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 07:38 Came to Los Angeles when Helen was in the 3rd grade.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 08:20 Graduated from Polytechnic High School in 1928.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 08:52 Korean community center in Bunker Hill area, 1920s.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 10:20 New Year's Day Hungsadan meetings.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 11:00 Apartment on Olive Court.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 12:00 Father's job at Graumann's Million Dollar Theater: hired to give Chinese atmosphere.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 14:20 Mother and father take care of apartment building.

creator: Voronaev, Yekaterina, interviewee
Воронаев, Екатерина, interviewee
title: Testimony of Yekaterina Voronaev, ca. 1960-1964
Свидетельство Екатерина Воронаевой, 1960?-1964?
sourceResource.description: Yekaterina Voronayeva, the wife of Ivan Efimovich Voronaev who was the founder of the Pentecostal Movement in Ukraine/Russia/USSR talks about her husband, his work, their life in the USA from 1911 through 1921 and then under the Soviet regime after they moved to Ukraine in 1921. She mentions a number of arrests and exiles she and Mr. Voronaev had gone through, then, she talks about her life after she saw him last time in 1936, and about the events that led to her return to the USA in 1960.

Kim no longer a church member; disenchanted after World War II.; Unit_ID: detail003. -- Title: 00:43 : Gives up organized religion following Korean War, but tries to live good Christian/Buddhist life.; Unit_ID: detail004. -- Title: 01:42 : Hypocrisy of religion and horror committed in name of God.; Unit_ID: detail005. -- Title: 02:30 : Studied the Bible extensively.; Unit_ID: detail006. -- Title: 03:57 : Involvement in campaign to build a monument to Japanese American World War II soldiers.; Unit_ID: detail007. -- Title: 05:07 : Conversation with interviewer about further interview times.

sourceResource.title: Rev. Kyong-t'ae Kang: Segment 1:
description: Interview abstract: Topics covered include Minister Kang's childhood and education under Japanese rule, escape from North Korea in 1949, the Korean War and postwar South Korea, his emigration to the USA in 1973, and Korean entrepreneurship in America.

sourceResource.title: Julia Kim Ide / Frank Kim / Betty Chung Kim: Segment 1:
Julia Kim Ide / Frank Kim / Betty Chung Kim: Segment 1:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:25 Julia introduces herself.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:49 Frank introduces himself.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:01 Betty introduces herself.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 01:13 Father was a minister in the King's cabinet, so had to flee to Merida, Mexico.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 03:04 When Father finished his contract, they went to Sonora, but he wasnted to go to USA.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 03:39 Sister, Mary, was sent to USA first with Mr. Park.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 05:12 Instead of the high school education she had been promised, Mary was forced to marry Mr. Park at age 13.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 07:04 Father upset at the loss of his daughter.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 07:28 Father died, probably of appendicitis.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 08:15 Father was a foreman in coal mines.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 09:14 Julia's memories of Sonora.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 10:34 Mary's husband smuggled the Kims into USA.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 11:10 When Mary divorced Mr. Park, he had the family deported back to Mexico.; Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 12:32 Their stepfather applied for the Kims to legally immigrate.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 13:14 Mary remarried, following her divorce from Mr. Park.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 13:48 Mary divorced again and married her third husband.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 15:25 Mary became a barber.

Young Oak Kim oral history: Segment 3:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:24 : Marries first wife in 1942, divorces in 1948.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 00:57 : Marriage dissolves because both were in Army and were kept apart.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 01:38 : Knew first wife since 5 years of age.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 02:11 : First wife proposed to him.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 02:40 : Reconnects with first wife in San Francisco.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 03:17 : At outbreak of World War II, stationed in Santa Rosa.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 03:55 : First wife one of first Asians to complete nursing school in late 1930s.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 04:40 : Late 1930s, limited employment opportunity for Asians.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 05:51 : Shortage of nurses leads to change in attitude towards Asian nurses.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 06:23 : Perception of Asian women as submissive.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 06:34 : Marries second time.; Unit_ID: detail012.--Title: 06:46 : First wife, Ida, half Chinese/half Korean; prominent father.; Unit_ID: detail013.--Title: 08:02 : Compares Ida's father with his own, in terms of drinking Unit_ID: detail014.--Title: 08:20 : Col. Kim's resentment towards this behavior.; Unit_ID: detail015.--Title: 08:44 : Awareness of male life in Korea.; Unit_ID: detail016.--Title: 10:01 : Boys "spoiled" in Korea.; Unit_ID: detail017.--Title: 10:16 : Considers himself spoiled, but less so, due to financial situation.; Unit_ID: detail018.--Title: 10:57 : First wife's full name--Ida Suhr.; Unit_ID: detail019.--Title: 11:06 : Second wife, Nora Chung, Korean by birth; raised by LA Chinese family.; Unit_ID: detail020.--Title: 11:28 : Nora's biological family put her up for adoption due to finances.; Unit_ID: detail021.--Title: 11:53 : Nora's father sells her to a Chinese couple.; Unit_ID: detail022.--Title: 12:07 : Nora's surname Yoon by birth, Chung by adoption.; Unit_ID: detail023.--Title: 12:25 : Second marriage lasts from 1955 to 1983.; Unit_ID: detail024.--Title: 12:40 : Marriage "goies on the blink" between 1963-1964; stays married out of habit.; Unit_ID: detail025.--Title: 13:04 : Met Nora at a Korean church; biological family supported Syngman Rhee.; Unit_ID: detail026.--Title: 13:45 : Nora's Chinese mother dies while she is in junior high; biological mother had never consented to adoption.; Unit_ID: detail027.--Title: 15:01 : Nora close to Mary Yoon.

sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:47 : Richard's grandparents, father (John (Sung Wu) Hahn) to USA in 1903, farmed in Taft, California.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 03:13 : Grandfather returned to northern Korea in 1929 to found a school for poor boys.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 05:10 : Richard born in Selma, California in 1922; to Los Angeles in 1934.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 05:51 : Father was very musical.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 07:18 : Richard graduated from Manual Arts High School in 1939 and joined the California Youth Corps.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 08:53 : Julia's father's (Kim In Sik) parents died, so he went to China, then to Hawaii.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 10:01 : Sent to Korea for a picture bride, which is how Julia's mother (Son So Nam) came.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 12:51 : Father was a farm laborer in Hawaii.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 14:05 : Father was older than the picture he sent to Korea.

sourceResource.title: Daniel Bhang / Audrey Bhang Lee: Segment 2:
Daniel Bhang / Audrey Bhang Lee: Segment 2:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:09 : Resented having to babysit, with no chance to play, other than drawing.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 02:09 : Restaurant was open every holiday; no days off.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 02:25 : [Daniel:] No inculcation into Korean culture.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 03:16 : After Chicago, moved to Dowagiac, Michigan.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 03:46 : Mother went berry picking and did piece work, pressing "ties".; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 04:54 : Audrey responsible for children's meals.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 06:20 : Father was usually away from home, working; not much family life.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 07:26 : Family moved around Michigan, farming / running a vineyard.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 10:20 : Finally got to start school by catching a truant officer's attention.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 12:58 : Had only heard Korean before the first day of school.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 14:06 : Teased by other children, but Audrey just enjoyed being with other children.

sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:01 : Discussion about lack of fear.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 01:00 : Other attributes of a gifted combat soldier.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 02:36 : Col. Kim also possessed an extraordinary tactical ability.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 02:55 : Uncanny ability to read a map and visualize it three dimensionally.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 03:33 : Also possessed timing and strategy, all qualities of gifted combat soldier.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 04:24 : Col. Kim considered by Army leadership as best combat soldier of 15,000.; Unit_ID: detail007.--Title: 06:13 : Military brought out Col. Kim's talents.; Unit_ID: detail008.--Title: 07:09 : Had respect even though not a West Point graduate; had more authority than his rank.; Unit_ID: detail009.--Title: 07:47 : Incident in Germany when he took over a military detail bungled by others.; Unit_ID: detail010.--Title: 10:08 : Given authority over those with higher rank; ability to see outside the box.; Unit_ID: detail011.--Title: 18:17 : Was treated with kid gloves in the Army.

sourceResource.title: Tae Eung Choi: Segment 1:
sourceResource.description: Unit_ID: detail001.--Title: 00:10 : Visit with family in North Korea, in spring 1989.; Unit_ID: detail002.--Title: 02:30 : Differences bwtween North and South Koreans.; Unit_ID: detail003.--Title: 05:02 : Because of just one man, Kil Il Sung, so many people live suppressed lives.; Unit_ID: detail004.--Title: 06:33 : Main interest in North Korean affairs is because of brothers living there.; Unit_ID: detail005.--Title: 07:53 : North Koreans in South Korea travel around in vagabond fashion; they "have no base," so appear to be more hard working.; Unit_ID: detail006.--Title: 09:10 : Cannot go back to Korea--North or South. Base is in US now.
